ext_descriptions.ext_description: A is an identifier of an unstructured mesh cell shape.
a single vertex.
A is an identifier of a topologically 1-D unstructured mesh cell shape.
a topological line requiring 2 vertices.
A is an identifier of a topologically 2-D unstructured mesh cell shape.
topologically quadrilateral (four sided) requiring 4 vertices;
topologically triangular (three sided) requiring 3 vertices
topologically polygonal (n-sided) requiring a minimum of 3 vertices;
A is an identifier of a topologically 3-D unstructured mesh cell shape.
topologically hexahedral (six quadrilateral faces) requiring 8 vertices.
topologically pentahedral (three quadrilateral faces and two triangular faces) requiring 6 vertices;
topologically tetrahedral (four triangular faces) requiring 4 vertices.
topologically pyramidal (one quadrilateral face and four triangular faces) requiring 5 vertices;
An specifies the allowable geometric order of the element interpolation functions of a finite element.
the element basic interpolation order is linear.
the element basic interpolation order is quadratic.
the element basic interpolation order is cubic.
An is a selection of a group of indices into a multi-dimensional array.
A is an enumeration of locations with respect to a mesh.
not specified;
via an external agreement between the data creator and the data user;
coincident with the mesh vertices;
the center of a cell; this is also appropriate for entities associated with cells but not necessarily with a given location in a cell;
the center of a generic face which can point in any coordinate direction;
the center of a face in 3-D whose computational normal points in the i direction;
the center of a face in 3-D whose computational normal points in the j direction;
the center of a face in 3-D whose computational normal points in the k direction;
the center of an edge.
A mesh maths space type is an enumeration of the kinds of associations of a mesh derived maths space and a mesh.
data is associated with mesh cells.
data is associated with mesh vertices.
A structured mesh type is an enumeration of the kinds of structured meshes.
a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, quadrilateral in 2-D, and hedral in 3-D.
a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, triangular in 2-D, and pentahedral, with 2 triangular and 3 quadrilateral faces forming a wedge-like shape, in 3-D.
a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, triangular in 2-D, and pyramidal in 3-D.
a structured mesh that is topologically linear in 1-D, triangular in 2-D, and tetrahedral in 3-D.

An Array_based_unstructured_mesh is a type of
that is a representation of an unstructured mesh designed to minimise the amount of data by not requiring explicit identification of the vertices of the cells in the mesh.
the vertex defined cells forming the mesh.
the value of index count shall be 1.

An is a type of
where the vertices of the mesh are explicity identified and ordered.
the number of unique vertex in the mesh
an array of the unique vertex in the mesh
the elements of vertices shall be all and only the unique vertices in the mesh.
A is a type of that is an identified cell of a structured mesh.
the structured mesh;
the indices of the cell;
the number of indices required to uniquely identify a vertex or cell in the mesh;
A is a relationship between two structured meshes that indicates one is part of the other.
the structured mesh that is part of the whole;
the structured mesh that contains the part;
the position of the vertex in the whole that is the origin of the part. This is specified with respect to each index of the whole.
the position of the face in the whole that is the origin of the part. This is specified with respect to each index of the whole.
the indices of the whole that are also indices of the part in the order that they are used in the part;

ext_description.p: the sense for each index of part as:

ul.li: TRUE if the part uses the index of the whole in the same direction;
FALSE if the part uses the index of the whole in the reverse direction;

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the number of indices required to uniquely identify a vertex or cell in the part;
the number of indices required to uniquely identify a vertex or cell in the whole;
A is a type of that is a representation of an unstructured mesh that is similar, but not entirely identical to, that specified in ISO 10303-104.
the finite element model;
the set of element representations comprising the mesh.

A Explicitly_defined_cell_patch is a type of
that is a patch that consists of cells and that is defined by listing them.
the collection of vertex defined cells.
An is a type of that is a patch that consists of vertices and that is defined by listing them.
the collection of vertex.
An is a list of indices into a multi-dimensional array.
the number of indices required to map to a unique array location;
the indices.
An is the beginning and ending indices of a subrange in a multi-dimensional array.
the number of indices required to map to a unique array location;
the indices of the minimal corner of the subrange;
the indices of the maximal corner of the subrange.

A Mesh is a type of
consisting of one or more cells. The mesh is the basis of all mesh topology representations. There are several ways of representing a mesh.
the text that provides further information about the .
the number of indices required to identify uniquely a vertex or cell in the mesh.
A is a type of that associates data values and a mesh.
the text that provides further information about the .
the words by which the is known.
the identifier for the .
the mesh
the kind of association
A is a type of that is a collection of one or more cells or one or more vertices. The cells are not necessarily connected.

ext_description.p: A is a relationship that is between:

ul.li: two operands that are a 1-dimensional mesh and an n-dimensional mesh; and
a product that is an (n + 1)-dimensional mesh,

ext_description.p: that indicates the (n + 1)-dimensional mesh is the Cartesian product of the operands. The ordering of cells and vertices of the product mesh is:

ul.li: cell i + n(j - 1) of the product mesh corresponds to cell i of the first operand and cell j of the second operand, where n is the total number of cells of the first operand;
vertex i + m(j - 1) of the product mesh corresponds to vertex i of the first operand, and
vertex j of the second operand, where m is the total number of vertices of the first operand.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: the two meshes that define the product;
the mesh that is the Cartesian product of the operands.
all meshes shall be structured meshes;
the first operand shall have an index count of one;
the index count of the product shall equal the sum of the index counts of the operands.
A Property_distribution_description is a
the identifier for the Property_distribution_description.
the words by which the Property_distribution_description is known.

the text that provides further information about the Property_distribution_description.
The value of this attribute need not be specified.
A describes the number of rind planes associated with a structured mesh.
the number of indices required to reference a vertex

ext_description.p: contains the number of rind planes attached to the minimum and maximum faces of a structured mesh. The face corresponding to each index n of planes in 3-D is:

example.p: For a 3D grid whose core size is II*JJ*KK, a value of planes = [a,b,c,d,e,f] indicates that the range of indices for the grid with this rind is:

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
A Structured_mesh is a type of
that has a regular topology. A structured mesh has a parametric coordinate system; the parametric coordinate systems for one- two-, and three-dimensional structured meshes are shown in Figure 11 through Figure 13.
For each cell within a structured mesh, the parametric coordinate system for that cell is identical to the parametric coordinate system for the mesh, except for an origin shift. The parametric coordinates of vertex (i, j, k) in a 3-D mesh with n, m and p cells in the 3 dimensions are: ((i - 1)/n, (j - 1)/m, (k - 1)/p)

he number of vertices in each dimension of the mesh. The product of the array elements is the number of vertices defining the mesh (i.e., excluding any rind points). The number of vertices in one- two- and three-dimensional regular mesh topologies is given in Figure X, where i, j and k correspond to the array elements vertex counts[1], vertex counts[2] and vertex counts[3], respectively.
the kind of mesh
A Structured_mesh_with_rind is a type of with specified rind planes.
the rind planes associated with the mesh.

A is a type of
that is a continuous point set with a single topological dimension.
the text that provides further information about the .
the topological dimension of the region.

A is a type of
that has a specified boundary.
the elements forming the boundary of the region.
A Topological_representation_item is a type of

An is a type of
where the topology need not be regular and the cell shapes are not restrained. It conceptually consists of the vertices of the mesh and the cells forming the volume of the mesh. The cells shall all be connected by each cell having at least one vertex in common with another cell. The shape of each cell in an unstructured mesh is explicitly specified.
the number of cells in the mesh.
A is a type of

A Vertex_defined_cell is a type of
that is bounded by vertices; the number of vertices depends on the topological shape of the cell. The cell may have interior nodes; the maximum number of interior nodes depends on both the shape and the order of the cell.
the topological shape of the cell;
the order of the cell geometric interpolation;

the the cell vertices and edge nodes. The position of a vertex or an edge node in the array depends on the shape of the cell as established graphically in Figures 10 through 39 in ISO 10303-104, noting that a polygon cell is a generalisation of the triangle and quadrilateral cells.
the number of cell bounding vertices; it is determined by the value of shape;
the number of interior cell nodes located on the cell edges; it is determined by the combination of the values of shape and order;
the potential number of interior cell nodes which are not located on the cell edges; it is determined by the combination of the values of shape and order;
the total number of bounding vertices plus the number of edge nodes; vn count: the total number of bounding vertices plus the number of nodes (both edge and non-dege nodes);
the vertices and nodes excluding any non-edge interior nodes. There shall be required count of these.

A is a type of
that consists of cells and that is defined by specifying a vertex range within a structured mesh.
the structured mesh;
the vertex range.
The function all mesh vertices takes an array based unstructured mesh and vertices as its argument and returns TRUE if the members of the vertices attribute are exactly the vertices in the mesh.
an array based unstructured mesh and vertices;
The function cell counts takes a vertex defined cell as its argument and returns the numbers of vertices and nodes required to define the cell.
a cell;
